commentBody:
ARTICLE...PIECE...STORY...


CROSSWORD.

Nice one Mr. Koski. I stared at that NW corner for 5 minutes, I had nothing at all. Until I remembered what a definite article is. 
Excellent Wednesday.

I solved this one slowly but steadily.  I got off on the wrong foot by plunking opal  in for 1A rather than MICA and later I tried oasis for shade in a a barren landscape, before coming up with OCHRE (clever clue).  I caught on to the theme towards the end and thought it was well worked out.  

I was happy to see Monty Python’s Michael Palin make an appearance.  I have watched all the Monty Python episodes  and movies.more times than I care to admit (along with John Cleese’s Fawlty Towers), and have many of the funniest bits memorized, and will launch into them if given the slightest encouragement.

I was a bit baffled by a few of the clues but sorted them all out, save one.
I had some figuring out what could be behind a drywall.
Luckily I came around to the right way of thinking...
Fun puzzle!

In the iOS app, I've just discovered that when I have Auto-Candidate Mode on in Sudoku, any candidates that I've removed come back whenever I fully fill in or remove a number. This isn't how it's behaved before. Is this intentional or a bug? I know any sudoku players who happen to be in these comments aren't likely to be sympathetic to someone who's not a "real" sudoku solver who does it exactly the same way someone with a pencil and eraser working on a paper puzzle would, but this still frustrates the way I play the game without feeling like a natural challenge, and might chase me away from playing the Times' Sudoku.
This was a Wednesday? No!
Bro get out of here with OPERAARIA. What are we even doing

Took some doing, but I reeled it in. Where I usually start, in the NW,  drew a complete blank at first, but filling in DEC finally let me in. 

I particularly liked the cynical yet fair "legit" hovering like commentary above "definite article" (1) but "fib" in a similar position murmured negatively over "speaks one's piece," as if to say even when we think we're being upfront & honest, it's only a version of the truth: may contain impurities, some fibs.  The lesson is, don't believe that every time someone CONFIDES IN you that it's the whole deal. You never know what lurks behind the pay wall!

Which brings me to the clever inclusion of DENY and PASS. And God forbid you have an ad-blocker. 

Small beef. Never liked TRA LA. Nobody hums Tra-la. At the very least, it'll be "tra-la-la."  If you hum tra-la you are not American. And only the definite article is American, haven't you heard from Our Leader? That the diversity initiatives undertaken by the elite puzzle cabalists who live in Pesto's Ridges, that glitzy gated community overlooking the Hudson, have now been revealed as the corrupt leftist agenda of the globalist deep state? PINO - puzzle in name only.

Where was I? Oh yes, tra-la must go. Seepy I can do without but it's a legit word, owly hardly ever used self-effacing pimply word that doesn't seep out much. What Ho for Seepy then! Give that word a PBR!

BELLLAP - just llllove it, and then the lively glottal stop of OPERA ARIA -- BOOM!

(1) [The] gets a second BOOM!

Terrific puzzle with a brilliant twist at the end.

I confidently filled in LIE for 26 across, but when I realize that 26 down started with an F, I changed it to FIG. 

Cover story, get it?

Finally got the happy music when I realized that a bell lap must be the last lap of a race. 

Thanks for the fun ride!

"Any evidence of Cinderella?"
"Just some prince at the scene."

("This case should be a shoe-in.")

Started off slowly in the NW, with the possibility of MICA in mind, but blanks on the crosses, so I held off. IGOR was my first fill in the NE, and that got me going, as filling in that area led to solving the first themer, and that led to me finishing the top of the puzzle. The rest of the puzzle filled in steadily, and I finished a little over my Wed. average.

A nice workout, and somehow I avoided having to correct any entries or typos. Thanks, Philip.
And here I thought one spoke one’s “PEACE.” Now I have to look up the origin of that one!
It was pretty chewy for a Wednesday, yet clueing was clever, and answers worked themselves out.   A wonderfully entertaining Wednesday puzzle.

Once again the fact that I always spell DEFINaTE wrong cost me time. The cross was a proper name I didn't know so that didn't help. Overall I'm a decent speller, but there are a handful of words that always trip me up. Nice puzzle with just the right amount of difficulty. I DEFINITEly enjoyed it.

Crossword Revolution Day 22:  FREE PRESS

It was there between the lines, the hidden theme.  (Almost went with SEEPY (“Flowing slowly”), which perfectly describes my brain these days).

A Crosswords Saved the Day ™ production.

I thought the themed answers were fun - DEFINITE ARTICLE made me smile. I assumed 44A would end in VICTORY before understanding theme which threw me off for a bit but managed to get back on track.

At the end, the middle section stumped me for longer than I would have liked for a Wednesday - didn't love the combination of TRA LA, SEEPY, BELL LAP, and IN A. Felt a little clunky. All in all a fun puzzle though!

I got away with murder on that one.

I don't know how many times I put something in and thought "I'll get back to that later", and then didn't have to because the music started.

Even though, 5D had me changing, one or two letter at a time from moore to PALIN.  There were a lot of famous satirists than came in between, like BALAS and the never to be forgotten SARIN.

Extra challenging for a Wednesday, lots of tricky clues, but not as scary as it looked at first.  Great fun and very satisfying.

Thank you Philip, for a welcome distraction. I NEED those, and I suspect that a lot of other people do too, especially if they're paying attention to the ONE UP in the White House, which I DID IN spades today, to the point of BURNOUT.  MADDening.

Challenging puzzle for me despite getting the theme!  I feel a bit silly asking this but — on 28 Down — When to wave the white flag.  Answer BELLLAP.  I honestly didn’t get this.  The only thing that remotely comes to mind is a swim meet?  Please anyone reading this, do tell!
The amount of double letters (LL, AA) was a doozy especially in the middle of the puzzle! I was stuck for awhile trying to fit in UNDERDOG in 44A. Thank you for the fun solve :-)

PAWAT   TRALA   OPERAARIA = Clunky! 

Nice theme, tho :)

Charming wednesday theme, though I agree with other commenters' gripes on TRALA and SEEPY

Also cute (accidental?) egg shape in the grid today. Reminds me of jackie and shadow 🦅

I just came here to do a slow clap for 20A. 
Best. 👏 Clue. 👏 Ever! 👏

Also feels like it should win some kind of prize for the biggest answer-to-clue length ratio (5:1, can anyone top that?)
1-hour New Yorker master class on The Art of the Crossword, with Robyn Weintraub and Natan last: https://www.newyorker.com/culture/video-dept/the-art-of-the-crossword

Uncharacteristically of the recent few weeks of NYT crossword puzzles, this grid was well suited to the day it ran on, methinks. I quite enjoyed it, even if I needed several lookups for some of the names and abbreviations.

Please help me understand: How is a TRAP where a wedge may be used?
Which sport both uses a white flag and uses the term “bell lap”?
OSHA before MADD. OPAL before MICA. This led to a slow solve in the NW corner.

1000 crossword streak obtained today. Can't believe that, to be honest. Been enjoying this week's puzzles, and last week's. Even subbed the 20 minutes on Sunday! Here's to another 1000 I hope I will do.

Strands Thread:


Strands #346
“Don't stop believin'”
🔵🔵🟡🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵


Conjure no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.  

When I got the theme I knew I was in big trouble.  Just picking out words in the top.

This was so much fun, and so very on my wavelength, until it all came to a crashing halt around the shaded squares. Maybe my brain is just SEEPY, but I’ve never heard of a BELL LAP, “not to go” was not sense making, and the only refrain I was hearing was “uh-uh, nope”. The top middle section was also a solid white rebuke for far too long.

But I cannot tell a FIB (or a “lie”, apparently), this puzzle was totally LEGIT. And while I did not earn a gold star today, the creator definitely deserves his.
Nice one today, Philip.  [The] for DEFINITE ARTICLE and [Shade in a barren landscape] for OCHRE were particularly clever.

Really clever puzzle. Tough and long workout for me, of course, but just a really nice 'aha' moment when I worked out the reveal and finally caught on to the trick. 

And can add in the clever clues for DEFINITEARTICLE and CINDERELLASTORY. Just added to the enjoyment.

And of course I have a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply.

...

Continuing the chewy Reformation that is Mr Shortz’ return, this was a thinker.
Love DEFINITE ARTICLE.  No clue to what 11D refers. pLC before the unknown LLC. Needed the explanation here to understand BELLLAP. What is a BIBB lettuce?

On the upside, the satirist and the TV star were gimmes.
Never heard of "Behind a Paywall" but then I don't get out much. :)

Clever idea well executed.  I've only scanned some of the comments but I appear to be alone in not knowing Ka LAE.    

Also an admirer of the clue [The] at 20A.  

Well done and thanks.
Sam, a “salami cap” is the mound shaped slice at the end that you share with the dog.

I didn't have much filled after my first pass, but somehow the theme clicked very early for me then the long answers helped me along. 

Clever clues!

Thoroughly enjoyed this lovely little bugger! Had me letter-swapping in the middle- Lie before FIB SEEPY, then SEaPY, and back again to SEEPY… OPERrettA (I know…) before OPERAARIA. And I can’t see Michael PALIN hovering over [Not to go] without thinking of Monty Python and the Holy Grail- “*Not* to leave the room, even if you come and get him!” https://youtu.be/g3YiPC91QUk?si=WnjxkEJDiH2BvRhS Brilliant!

Solved this one almost 8 minutes over my average today, but without lookups! Stumbled in the SE corner with Bud instead of PBR for 63D but quickly realized that couldn’t be right. The top third was blank except for IGOR but eventually decided to try MICA for 1A and then things started to fall in place. 

I was a bit confused by the theme because I thought the first half of the answers were supposed to have something to do with the paywall and I couldn’t figure it out. The constructor’s notes made some sense of that, I guess.

The price you pay for filling in a word too quickly!

Things went very smoothly, even though I didn't really see how the themers related to either the shaded words or the revealer.

No, the problem is that I too quickly jumped on LicIT for 18A; it seemed plausible, although not the usual use of the word. Still, that left me at a loss in that one little section.

The remedy, as usual: wipe out what once seemed so promising and start over.

Thank you!
I am honestly surprised at the phrase “speaks ones piece”. I was convinced it was flat out wrong. I’ve only ever heard of “speaking one’s peace”. So I had to google it and I guess “today I learned…”.

A most marvelous moment for me came with [One leg curl, e.g.], for REP, where I was imagining forever a person on a leg curl machine working on a single leg at a time, and I kept thinking, “There must be a name for that exercise and what do you call that type of exercise?” I kept coming back to it, thinking, “It’s going to come to me!  It’s going to come to me!”

When the correct interpretation finally hit me it brought one of Crosslandia’s best moments: The HahaAha!

For me this was as hard as a Saturday and a hard Saturday at that. Everything made sense after I got it filled in but getting to the actual answer was challenging because they were off the beaten track of idiom.  Very enjoyable!

This was a classic Wednesday for me. You can solve it without knowing the theme, but it makes it more fun if you figure it out. Whereas for Thursday, often you can't solve it without knowing the trick. 
Nice puzzle, Philip!

Philip’s last puzzle (6/8/23) wowed me with its wit and intelligence, and I couldn’t wait to dive into this one.  It didn’t disappoint:
•	A wide range of knowledge – History, geography, sports, arts, grammar, work, food, pets, and of course, journalism.
•	Loveliness in answer: CINDERELLA STORY, ANY IDEAS, INSIGNIA, TAIL WAG, and the swelll (BELLLAP).
•	Areas of fight leading to gratifying flashes of insight, followed by glorious splat fills.
•	Gorgeous layered theme graphically illustrating the relatable BEHIND A PAYWALL.
•	Unintended graphic art – that mid-grid tree or lollipop, either of which push my happy-button.
•	Clues that misdirected, to my brain’s delight, such as those for OCHRE, TRAP, and REP.  

Once again, the stamp of quality, and I’m a fan, Philip.  Thank you for a splendid solve!

This was one of those puzzles where I filled in what first came to mind, added letters that seemed to fit the gaps, and like a stereogram it slowly came into focus.
A very well constructed Wednesday!

If your barren landscape is too seepy, a sepia might flow slowly into the ochre area, and then wadi you have? (rhetorical question)

And isn’t the plural just “operas”, not “operaaria”? (r.q. #2)

Seepy? (This one I want an answer to.)
Ugh, please fix the software. More and more Ive completed the puzzle, get the completion screen and music. Then the clock keeps ticking.
Michael Palin a satirist? Tenuous!
Tough Wednesday workout!

Not knowing the use of a white flag in racing, combined with not knowing what a bell lap is, made the middle especially tough for me. I did get them from the crosses, but googled "bell lap white flag" to confirm it was right. I started reading what turned out to be a a Reddit post about this particular puzzle, which revealed a couple of answers that I hadn't gotten to before I realized what was looking at. Other than that accidental boost, no lookups...but I'm not sure I would have been able to complete the puzzle without it.

I started this one last night in bed, went to sleep without being able to complete it, and had vivid crossword dreams all night.
Huh, the first 15x16 puzzle I've seen. Well done.

Tripped up by some spelling errors and wondering when one may wear a SALAmi cap.

Thank Philip, an excellent Wednesday.

I found this crossword to be rather confusing and tricky, wondering how everything fit together.  Only after staring at the finished puzzle for a few minutes did the "AHA" moment come, and I smiled from ear to ear.  Congrats on a very clever puzzle.
Some really gross fill in the middle. This one needed a bit more time in the oven to finish baking.

Mr. Koski's comments about journalists reminded me of a press conference I attended long ago while working as a freelance science writer. I usually knew quite a lot about a subject before starting a story, and then had a few weeks to complete the article. At the press conference about the health effects of eating fish caught locally from the St. Lawrence, I recognized a regular from the evening news. He was asking really basic, kinda naive questions -- clearly starting with little knowledge of the topic. I watched him on tv that evening. He delivered a super concise and accurate summary, and in an authoritative tone that made you think he really knew what he was talking about. OK, it's not rocket science, but health can be a tricky topic to get right. I was truly impressed. 

Great theme. Fun puzzle.
Am I the only one who got nothing? My first puzzle I got zilch nada nothing.

Not a fan of this one at all. 

Way too difficult for a Wednesday. What has been in the water this week? They've all been bad. 

Gave up and pressed "reveal all" at about the 70% mark because I didn't have the patience for this one today. 

Pass.

My first thought on 46D was how could I go through primary school and never learn the southern most point in the U.S.?  Once I learned the location of Ka Lae it made a little more sense.  Hawaii became a state about the same time I entered first grade, so I am sure it took a while for the geography books to get updated.  Ka Lae may have been in the puzzle before, but I don't recall it.  Next time I bet I do.
Lots of “ok, I guess that sort of fits” instead of “oh, that’s clever.”

A moderate Wednesday for me; finished around 20 percent under my average time for the day. A wonderful theme, I thought…and as former newspaper and magazine writer, I’m all for pay walls, though of course they frustrate me at times…but I recognize their importance for getting writers/photographers/editors paid. When people I know complain, I always ask: would a plumber fix your faucet for free.

One small memory flash from 30A (SPEAKS ONE’S PIECE): 

In 1986, I was laid off from the regional magazine where I worked. Pretty quickly, I got hire at an alternative weekly, where I worked with a marvelous journalist, J A Lobbia, who was under five feet tall but fierce in every way. As the two staff writers, we shared our work with each other as a check before it went to the editor.  I had ambitions in creative writing and if I pushed those tendencies too far, when I gave her one of my stories to read, she’d snap, “You’re just showing off.” She was always right and I’d cut the show-offy parts before I turned it in.

One day, when I handed her my work, I said, “Here’s my piece.” She said, “This is a newspaper. We call them articles.”

I left the paper after three years to get an MFA in fiction, then joined the faculty at a mid-sized university. JA ended up at the Village Voice, where, even from 900 miles away, I could tell she was still fierce. Sadly, she died at 43, in 2001. So, thanks, Phillip Koski, for the nudge to remember her.

I feel like there could have been different clue for DEFINITEARTICLE rather than just 'The'. But the theme helped with filling in ARTICLE and then there wasn't really anything I could think of besides DEFINITE. Quite a few new words for me, including BIBB, TRALA, and BELLLAP.

Well, you either use a white flag *or* a bell to signal the last lap of a race. The former in car racing (as a visual sign for drivers in a noisy race), the latter in track and field (because runners can hear the ringing bell). 

But you would never use them both at the same time. 

I love misleading/misdirecting clues. But not ones like 28D where you think "well, it can't be that because...." (all the above reasons). 

So many other/better/clever ways to clue this one - like "When to begin your final kick".
This one was a bugger, but proud to say I got in 26 minutes.

Nice, LEGIT Wednesday puzzle. I had both legal and licit first. Uber before ABET.  All that was quickly straightened out with the certainty that WAGE (gap) was correct. 
LAE was my last fill - because I didn't know it! Also because I was stubbornly trying to find a one-word answer to the Mozart clue.
We got an inch of snow overnight - just enough that I had to shovel off the sidewalk and clean off the car. Sitting down for puzzling and coffee was a great reward.

Got to reading the Comments (and commenting on the Comments) and forgot to join in and post my own Comment.

Bravo, Philip Koski!  This was neat.  I enjoyed the solve even  though I had to retrace my steps several times (I see I had a lot of company) which always means I'm beiing put through my paces.  This is good for me, I understand.  So they tell me.  I get it.  Fine.

I wanted The Big UNIT but then I think he was pitching for Seattle...when the Cleveland Indians lost...again.

I'm from the generation of women who know all about the workplace WAGE gap and SALARY cap and WALLs and ceilings.

Speaking of boldly. I like to play the Sudoku on my phone. The Candidate numbers are way too small to read. Is there any way to make the Candidate numbers in bold and/or bigger? It would make things much easier. Can you direct me to the Sudoku editor?

OPERA ARIA?

Ok, sure. Not to be confused with a witness aria.



Once more with feeling.

Good puzzle. It's the DEFINITE ARTICLE, the real thing.
But not much fun.

A few iffy or awkward answers, to my mind. 
SEEPY? feels like a made-up word.
OPERA ARIA? redundant and awkward.
BELL LAP? I had hoped the cover story wasa FIG leaf.
Red Sox and the screen play seemed natick-y.
(I doubt I'm unique in these nits, I'll read the column and comments in a bit.)

And near the end, BURN OUT BLEAKLY.
That's what doom scrolling current news will do to ya.

I love the theme and I thought all the theme clues were well done! It’s just held back by weak fill - TRALA, OPERAARIA, SEEPY, etc. Would like more from this constructor, just need them to focus on nailing the rest of the puzzle as well as they nailed the theme.
Why are all of the Wednesday puzzles so awful this year? Terrible cluing with a lame theme.

At a shotgun wedding, the minister says, "Speak now, or forever hold your PIECE."

Some fun stuff today, "campus grilling" for ORALS had me going for a while. Just a note; the RIDGES on the edges of coins are to discourage shaving off bits of silver, which is a thing that people did. It seems like a lot of work for not much return. Anyway, not necessarily about counterfeiting.

I’m going to speak my piece quite frankly. As this puzzle seemed to be a bit harder than most Wednesdays based on my time. It felt bleak for a while but the Cinderella story came out on top and was not denied.
Too much head scratching for a Wednesday. Meh!
OPERA ARIA might be my least favorite crossword entry of all time.

Anyone else think "City that was a rival of ancient Sparta" was a gimme, and confidently put in Athens, only to find that it didn't fit...and wonder whether there might be a Wednesday rebus in the puzzle?

The leap from pay in the sense of a SALARY or WAGE (received compensation) to the cost of a subscription for access seems forced.  

Less “Oh, I see!” than “I guess so.”

Took me almost 30 minutes, which made it especially challenging for a Wednesday. Unusual theme, to say the least. 

SEEPY/BELLLAP took quite some time for me to see.

Given the constraints of the complex theme, the fill was OK---though OPERAARIA and SEEPY seemed a bit desperate.

A Wednesday that I had to finish in the morning. 😅 Tough one today with a lot of misdirection (for me anyway), but that’s what keeps me at it every day. I was 12 minutes over my average! Big PAPI was a gimme as my husband’s Uncle Dick was the VP of Public Relations for the Red Sox. My father in law even chose Poppie as his grandfather name 😉  I really enjoyed this one, so thank you, Philip.

When I got to the clue for 20A, I laughed so hard I couldn't continue to type for awhile. Just had to sit there and admire the audacity.

And accept that this was not gonna be a quick one.

The first time through the Across clues, I guessed LAYSITONTHELINE for 30A. It fit the fill, and seemed reasonable from the clue. That mistake slowed down getting some (a lot) of the crosses! My second pass was working the Down clues from top to bottom, and since I didn't have many fills, trying to think of answers that fit with it wasn't going very well. I think it was when I got to 34D that I figured out it was wrong. 🤓
Erasing it made things go much smoother.
Anybody else say THE definite article, like a college footballer would say THE Ohio State University?  Just me?

Screwed up the NW with OPAL at 1A.

Took a little time to straighten that out.

Fun puzzle!
Ka Lae may be the southernmost point of the 50 states, but it is not the southernmost point of the US, which includes  several South Pacific territories.

I've recently started working through the archive. It is refreshing to do puzzles that are, frankly, challenging again. Too many of the current puzzles seem to be so easy, and they still garner copious complaints from people who find them too hard. I think the complainers have won - the puzzles have been dumbed down as a result. 

I have a couple of questions.

1. For those who have already been working through the archive -- sometimes you mention reading the accompanying comments. I have been unable to find them. I am still in 1993 -- were there no comments then? I suspect not, since the WWW barely existed then. (I first started using the WWW in 1995, and it was very new then.) When did the comments start, and how when I get to that date, will there be an easy way to find them? 

2. In the December 10, 1993 puzzle, the clue for 3D is "Attic contest" and the answer is AGON.  Can someone explain this to me? I know that, among other definitions, AGON is a theatrical device, often used in Greek theater. Is this a typo: should the clue have been "Attica contest" instead of "Attic contest"? 

Please note that I am not complaining or spewing hatred at the constructor or editor (Will Shortz). I am not going on and on about how this is completely wrong, or that it ruined the puzzle for me, or ruined my entire day. (Yes, I have seen that last gripe more than once, and it is stunning to me that a simple crossword puzzle could in any way ruin someone's entire day.) 

Any "attic" help?
A struggle for a Wednesday but made it through!!!
52A would be a good title for this puzzle. Especially since its a questionable clue.
Great column Sam!

I got stumped early on and spent 2.5 hours on this. Started at 10 pm last night, and didn’t see the Cinderella reference, because, you guessed it, I’d already turned into a pumpkin by then. But this my first 10-day streak.
This was fun and chewy for me. Getting DEFINITE ARTICLE for “the” off the bat with no crossings was a little thrill.
Man would’ve had a fast one but Bell Lap flummoxed me

When your personal life gets too involved in your crossword, you enter things like hot immediately at 27D for ___ flash, forgetting that you were pretty sure 26A was most likely either lie or FIB. Oops!

At least I got to BURNOUT BLEAKLY. That sums it up nicely. TRALA (la).

Pretty fun puzzle!  Most things didn't just fall into place but it was fun to, well, puzzle it all out and it all stayed lively for me in about average Wednesday time. I was not DIDIN!

DEFINITEly enjoyed 20A DEFINITEARTICLE! That was great!

Well, I spoke my PIECE... Now it's back to work I go....

Oh no. I think I am becoming an assess-er of  puzzles.

I liked this one quite a bit. It was more challenging than the typical Wednesday, IMHO, and by and large it was fun.

Took me forever to get the type of story that is in the middle, but that was on me.

There were a couple of clunky entries, which put a small dent in my enjoyment.

"Seepy" seemed a bit of a stretch, and I avoided entering those letters for a while, but that slowed me down only a little since I had no idea about the white flag.

I liked the theme, but figuring it out only provided confirmation of the easier parts of the themed entries, so I didn't get the rush when getting the theme splits things wide open.

But hey, I am sure the puzzle was a challenge to create, and overall, it was done very well.

Tough one but I persisted. 

Got that "Oh Rats" alert and spent another ten minutes before realizing that screen play was pass rather than pads, which after entering I never had any faith in. 

I enjoyed it and found the theme quite clever.
It was certainly looking very iffy for me there for a while but like others I persisted and got my first ever 7 streak. Fun puzzle, especially BELL LAP. Now on to 8…

In the app, when I click on the links to scroll down to theme or tricky clues, it redirects me to the main NYT page. I am assuming I'm not the only one this is happening to, because that would be really weird. I just wanted to verify.

Anyway, fun puzzle today!

re: the slew of comments regarding 28D [When to wave the white flag], I just want to point out that while NASCAR may not ring a bell, they do refer to it as the BELL LAP. Link and quote below, but you have to agree to cookies to see the piece. The things I do for you people. ;) https://www.nascar.com/news-media/2024/10/27/ryan-blaney-falls-one-spot-shy-at-homestead-miami-in-dramatic-finish/ Ryan Blaney was leading at the bell lap, about to join his Team Penske teammate Joey Logano in the Championship 4 at Phoenix Raceway to be the second title contender to lock in and find the late momentum he was looking for to defend his NASCAR Cup Series title. Tyler Reddick, however, had other plans.

Am I imagining it, or was there a comment earlier today from David Connell explaining why OPERA ARIA is not as redundant as some people claim?

I wanted to thank David for his knowledgeable observation. 

I can’t imagine why that comment would have been deleted.

“I Know That My Redeemer Liveth” Aria for soprano from the Oratorio “Messiah” by G. F. Handel https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Kg7aXEvCeXY&pp=ygUdaSBrbm93IHRoYXQgbXkgcmVkZWVtZXIgbGl2ZXM%3D “Aus Liebe will mein Heiland sterben” soprano aria from the “Saint Matthew Passion” by J. S. In hopes of seeing a comment appear (Wednesdays seem to be my best hope), I wanted to follow up on the “lay” controversy.

Many of the minority who reacted positively to a ballad and a lay belonging together cited reading Tolkien.

Though Tolkien is famous for inventing words, languages, histories and myths in his works, I’m afraid too few people who’ve read and even loved his works appreciate how much of it was _not_ invented. 

Hythe, sward, gore, ling, gorse, copse, fen…just a few of hundreds of English words he employed for landscapes.
Orc, troll, ent, fell-beast; dwimmor, delving, farthing; the months thrimidge, solmath, etc. - all taken directly from the Old English.

I used to urge my students to look up everything, including words you think you know. Writers of dictionaries worked their lives through to put that information there for you.

And every word by a good author is intentional:
Walt Whitman wrote

“I saw in Louisiana a live-oak growing…”

Both Louisiana and live-oak must be known before this poem can achieve its end. It is not a pine tree in Maine; it is not a cottonwood in New Mexico. It is on the _reader_ to understand a good author. m

Never hesitate to look up words you think you know. More so, words you know you don’t know.

@Hardroch interesting. Having visited Southernost Point in Key West many times, I recently went down a rabbit hole and learned about Ballast Key. It is a very small island key in the direction of Fort Jefferson. It is only accessible by boat, and privately owned. It has a storied history, with the famous Key West Developer David Wolkowsky (who developed much of Key West in the 1960s/70s) building a home there. An interesting story worth a Google search. He entertained many famous guests, including heads of state, authors and artists on the island. On his death, he willed the island to the Nature Conservancy, which oversees a protected bird and marine animal habitat and research center there.
